title-group.article-title: PRELIMINARY INSIGHTS IN OXYTOCIN ASSOCIATION WITH THE ONSET OF DIABETIC NEUROPATHY

article-meta.aff: 1“Prof. Dr. Al. Obregia” Clinical Psychiatry Hospital - Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Department, “Carol Davila” University of Medicine and Pharmacy - Bucharest, Romania
2Physiology and Fundamental Neuroscience Department - Bucharest, Romania
5Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Department, Bucharest, Romania
6“Prof. N. Paulescu” National Institute of Diabetes, Nutrition and Metabolic Diseases - Dermatology, Bucharest, Romania
7“Victor Babes” National Institute of Pathology - Immunology Department, Bucharest, Romania
8University of Bucharest, Faculty of Biology - Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Department, Bucharest, Romania

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence to: Calin Petru Tataru MD, “Carol Davila” University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Division of Ophthalmology, Alexandru Lahovari Square no 1, Bucharest, 010464, Romania, E-mail: calinpetrutataru@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Diabetes is one of the most prevalent chronic disorders, associating numerous somatic and behavioral modifications. Oxytocin has been widely studied for its involvement in social behavior and psychiatric disorders.

This pilot study presents a series of 3 patients with type 1 diabetes and diabetic neuropathy in which the values of plasma oxytocin, neurotensin, β-endorphins, α-MSH, substance P and orexin A were measured in comparison to 3 healthy controls with matching ages.

In the diabetic patients group, there was a strong negative correlation between the value of plasma glucose and oxytocin (r=-0.99, p=0.04), respectively neurotensin (r=-0.99, p=0.03). These values did not correlate in the control group.

The results suggest that oxytocin, in conjunction with neurotensin, could be investigated as a potential early detection marker of diabetic neuropathy and, to our knowledge, this is the first report focusing on plasma oxytocin levels in patients with diabetic neuropathy.
